awd_titl_txt: Seismic Strain Along the San Adreas Fault System
awd_abstract_narration: This research will investigate the 3-D seismic strain and stress              as a function of distance along the San Andreas fault system.  A                moving average of the tensoral seismic strain field and state of                stress will be computed using the existing seismic network data.                Results will be related to detailed fault geometry, rates of creep,             temporal and spatial proximity to earlier large earthquakes, and                will be compared to numerical models of the fault.  Preliminary                 results indicate that the principal compression is approximately                normal to the fault where rates of creep are high, but oblique to               the fault as creep falls off toward the north.  Variation of                    tensoral strain components along the fault length appear related                to fault ends, but also systematically change as a function of                  creep rate.  This research is a component of the National                       Earthquake Hazard Reduction Program.
